awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The physical and chemical dynamics of groundwater flow across the land-sea interface in Arctic lagoon ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal areas in the Arctic are changing rapidly, with increases in river flow, coastal erosion, and permafrost thaw, and as underground ice melts, thin, shallow aquifers develop. At the same time, the amount, organic and inorganic nutrient content, and pathways of coastal groundwater have been understudied and remain poorly understood in the Arctic. This study will combine field measurements and numerical modeling to characterize groundwater flow to Beaufort Sea lagoons and how it changes across seasons and years. The project will train undergraduate and graduate students, disseminate the knowledge gained to communities close to the study area and near the investigators’ institutions, including K-12 students and local agencies involved in managing the Arctic coast, create and broadcast content for public education, and provide data and tools to help understand fundamental processes in the Arctic.  

This project will provide fundamental new knowledge regarding groundwater flow and biogeochemical processes in lagoon systems along the Alaskan Beaufort Sea coast. The primary research objectives are: 1) to determine the mechanisms and pathways for groundwater flow across the land-lagoon interface and how these mechanisms and pathways evolve seasonally; and 2) to understand seasonally-varying fluxes, sources, and lability of groundwater-derived dissolved organic matter and inorganic nutrients delivered to lagoons along the eastern Alaskan Beaufort Sea coast. A suite of methods will include isotopic, biogeochemical, hydrologic, and geophysical field measurements of groundwater flow and solute transport across the land-lagoon interface during spring ice-break-up, later summer open water season, and until winter freeze up. The investigators will interpret the observations and develop physical insight using computation flow and transport modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Arctic lagoons serve as critical ecosystems that support biodiversity and provide key resources for coastal communities. These environments are undergoing rapid changes due to climate warming, with significant consequences for hydrological and biogeochemical processes. This project aimed to investigate how groundwater flow and associated chemical transport across the land-sea interface influence the structure and function of Arctic lagoon ecosystems.

Our research provided new insights into the physical and chemical processes governing groundwater discharge into Arctic lagoons. Using a combination of field measurements, geochemical tracers, and numerical modeling, we demonstrated that groundwater contributions to Arctic lagoons are more dynamic than previously thought. Seasonal changes in permafrost thaw and hydrological connectivity drive fluctuations in groundwater discharge, influencing nutrient and carbon fluxes into these coastal environments.

Key findings include:

  • Groundwater discharge is a significant source of nutrients, including nitrogen and silica, which support primary production in Arctic lagoons.

  • Submarine groundwater discharge (SGD) is spatially heterogeneous and varies seasonally, influenced by permafrost thaw dynamics and precipitation patterns.

  • Freshwater inflows alter the salinity gradients in lagoons, impacting microbial activity and ecosystem function.

  • The release of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) from terrestrial groundwater inputs contributes to coastal carbon cycling and may have implications for greenhouse gas emissions.

  • Radium isotope analyses revealed seasonal variations in SGD, with higher discharge rates in ice-free periods driven by wind-induced hydrological changes.

  • Findings challenge the assumption that SGD is negligible in regions with continuous permafrost, showing that Arctic SGD can be comparable to temperate regions.

This project contributed to workforce development by providing training opportunities for early-career scientists, graduate students, and undergraduate researchers. Fieldwork in Arctic Alaska engaged students in hands-on data collection, analysis, and interdisciplinary collaboration.

Additionally, the research findings have implications for Indigenous coastal communities that rely on Arctic lagoons for subsistence fishing and other ecosystem services. Our collaboration with local stakeholders helped integrate traditional ecological knowledge with scientific observations, fostering a more comprehensive understanding of environmental change. Public outreach activities, including presentations and digital storytelling, helped communicate our findings to broader audiences.

By addressing critical knowledge gaps in Arctic hydrology and biogeochemistry, this project has laid the groundwork for future research on climate-driven changes in groundwater-lagoon interactions. Our findings underscore the importance of considering groundwater as a key component of Arctic coastal systems and provide a basis for developing better predictive models to inform conservation and management efforts in these vulnerable environments.
